4.58.text:
>> Paul: So today's talk
is by Dr. Ned Gilbert.

9.60.text:
He's a research team
leader with the UCL

13.78.text:
and other institution
Extreme Everest expeditions.

18.82.text:
So he's going to talk about
the previous one and also talk

22.11.text:
about the new one
that's just coming up.

25.88.text:
>> Dr. Ned Gilbert:
Thank you very much.

31.86.text:
So today I am talking
about Extreme Everest II,

35.43.text:
which is an expedition
we're undertaking

37.67.text:
in about two months' time,
but I'll also be talking

40.88.text:
about a little bit about
the previous expedition

45.03.text:
By background, I'm
a medical doctor.

47.30.text:
I'm an anesthetist, an
intensive care doctor,

49.57.text:
but I've taking time
out of my clinical work

52.45.text: to do a Ph.D. here at UCL.

58.05.text:
I guess you could call it a
problem, talk in medical lingo.

60.69.text:
So I really try to not
talk in medical lingo.

63.44.text:
So please shout at me
if I do start going off

68.68.text:
So, in summary, what I talk
about today, what I'm going

71.21.text:
to talk about case
medicine, which is the group

76.34.text:
what we do at case
medicine, and why we do it.

79.36.text:
Gives you an idea why we
do these crazy things.

81.32.text:
The first expedition,
which was done in 2007,

89.42.text:
which is I say we're
in the process of.

92.99.text:
Beforehand, though,
I'd just like to go

95.31.text:
through what we call
a clinical case.

97.22.text:
As a doctor, when you're in
hospital, whether you've been

100.14.text:
in hospital, whether
you're a doctor,

101.36.text:
you'll find yourself
presented as this really.

106.25.text:
So if I present a
clinical case to you all,

111.24.text:
He describes himself
as fit and well,

113.40.text:
though you may argue
otherwise if you knew the chap.

116.27.text:
He's got no significant
medical history.

120.49.text:
He's 67 kilograms, and
he's 178 centimeters tall.

126.45.text:
When you look at him, and
we like to look at people,

130.13.text:
we do this A, B, C that
you may have heard about,

136.23.text:
His [inaudible] which he's
breathing is 60 breaths

145.81.text:
His oxygen saturation is when we
measure how much oxygen he's got

148.88.text:
in his blood should be
around 99 or 100 percent,

151.26.text:
is about 34 percent, and his
heart rate is double the normal.

155.92.text:
So it's as if he's just
been sprinting 100 meters.

158.90.text:
He's got normal blood pressure,
and his [inaudible] coma scale,

162.12.text:
which tells us neurologically
how intact he is,

166.44.text:
So he's fully lucid,
chatting, coherent, and happy,

169.39.text:
but his numbers are
really, really odd.

171.74.text:
And now in hospital, if
he were to go to ANE,

174.63.text:
and you were very unwell,
and you had a chest infection

177.44.text:
or something, and you had a
chest infection or something,

179.37.text:
and you had numbers anywhere
near this, or even half of that

181.55.text:
as these were, as a doctor would
take some blood from your wrist,

185.29.text:
and look at how oxygenated
that blood is,

188.20.text:
and we measure the
oxygen in that blood.

191.17.text:
So if were to take some oxygen
from anyone in this room,

193.26.text:
some blood, and measured
the oxygen levels,

195.06.text:
the number would be
about 15 kilopascals.

199.22.text:
If we do that in ANE, and
a patient has a blood level

203.99.text:
of about 8, we really
get worried,

206.05.text:
and we'll call the
intensive care doctors,

208.38.text:
and they'll contemplate putting
this person into an induced coma

211.18.text: and putting them on a ventilator

212.29.text:
because 8 is a worryingly
low number for oxygenation.

216.52.text:
So this chap, we did
a blood gas on him,

223.62.text:
So that is very, very
low, and, in fact,

226.17.text:
I've never ever seen an oxygen
level anywhere near that.

228.88.text:
Anywhere even near 5
in hospital setting,

232.38.text:
and it's actually the
lowest number ever recorded

235.04.text:
for a blood oxygen
level in a live patient.

237.15.text:
And he's very proud if
you ever meet this person.

241.20.text:
So where did we meet
this person?

242.94.text: Well, this is where I work

244.42.text:
on a day-to-day basis,
and it wasn't here.

247.41.text:
I mean, if it had been here,
I would have been extremely,

250.56.text:
I'd be very worried, indeed,
but it was, in fact, here.

256.05.text:
It's covered with this
ominous-looking [inaudible] form

258.80.text:
cloud on top of it, and if you
look at the screen to the right,

261.96.text:
you can almost see
a little balcony,

263.29.text:
and the chap we've just
described had just been

266.23.text:
up to summit, and
had just decided

270.93.text:
On his way down, they
put up a little tent,

272.63.text:
and they thought it would be a
good idea to drop their trousers

276.01.text:
and get a friend who had equally
as little oxygen in his blood

279.86.text:
to get a big needle and
put it in his groin.

282.66.text:
Rather him than me,
but they did do it,

285.41.text:
and that's where he
got the numbers from.

287.41.text:
So why on Earth or
what persuaded someone

289.98.text:
to drop their trousers on
the summit of Mount Everest

292.08.text: to be stabbed with a needle?

293.61.text:
Well, I have to go back
to the very beginning

295.27.text:
to explain why they
wanted to do that,

297.40.text:
what they found,
and what is useful.

299.76.text:
Of note also in this
slide is there's a chap

302.71.text:
in a yellow jacket, and he's
the Sherpa that led them

306.95.text: up the top of the summit.

308.15.text:
Twenty-four people
went up to the summit.

310.24.text:
This was in the 2000
expedition, and they were led

312.61.text:
by this Sherpa, who looks
like he's doing a runner,

315.17.text:
and he was actually
doing a runner

316.38.text:
because in his thermos flask is
not a good bit of British tea,

319.58.text:
but it's some blood samples,
and he's about to run

322.60.text:
down the mountain to
analyze those samples.

325.35.text:
And to give you an
idea, the team.

327.64.text:
So Dan, who had his blood taken,
they descended from the summit

330.69.text:
to base camp in about
48, 49 hours.

333.17.text:
This Sherpa ran down the
mountain in an hour and a half.

337.52.text:
So they're pretty remarkable
people, and we'll come back

342.01.text:
If you ever do it,
walk down, don't run.

343.57.text:
So, as I said, I have to explain
what they were doing there,

350.49.text:
So it goes back to
case medicine.

353.15.text:
Now case medicine is, belongs
to UCL, and it's the center

356.45.text:
of altitude, space, and
extreme environment medicine,

359.28.text:
and it was set up in
about the year 2000

362.36.text:
by two doctors who
work here now.

364.95.text:
A chap who's now a professor at
Down South called Mike Grocott

367.69.text:
and a doctor called Kevin
Farm, who's always on TV.

370.91.text:
Now these doctors are intensive
care doctors, and they,

374.93.text:
as they strolled
around their wards,

376.23.text:
found that about 90
percent of patients

378.01.text:
in intensive care suffer from
problems with oxygenation

381.90.text:
and low levels of oxygen, and
they use a word called hypoxia

386.83.text:
or hypoxic, which means
is if someone is hypoxic,

389.84.text:
it means they have suffering
from low levels of oxygen.

392.78.text:
I'll try and not use that
word, but if I do say it,

394.90.text: it gives you an idea why.

398.79.text:
90 percent of our patients
are suffering from low levels

401.14.text:
of oxygen, be it, because
they've got problems

403.00.text:
with breathing, because of
problems with their heart.

407.98.text:
but they had problems
with oxygenation.

410.86.text:
They also know that in
medicine, to progress treatment

418.40.text:
So to bring out a new
treatment, you have to go

420.59.text:
through clinical trials,
show that it's better

422.39.text:
than what's standing,
and so forth.

425.01.text:
But the problem in intensive
care is these patients are

427.04.text:
so unwell, they're often
in these induced comas.

430.04.text:
So, a., they can't consent; b.,
families are very unwilling,

434.50.text:
quite rightly, to consent their
relatives, their loved ones

441.19.text:
and [inaudible] can
be troublesome to get.

444.29.text:
So they came up with
this paradigm, really,

447.33.text:
and they thought that
perhaps the physiological

451.41.text:
to an extreme environmental
challenge, such as going

454.15.text:
to high altitude, may be
similar to those responses

457.54.text:
or those responses we
see in critical illness.

460.75.text:
So if we talk about the
low levels of oxygen,

463.63.text:
90 percent of patients
have low levels

466.60.text:
Upper high mountain where
the pressure's much lower,

469.59.text:
everyone up there suffers
from low levels of oxygen.

471.63.text:
So they thought going very
high would mirror being

475.64.text:
The low oxygen up
there would be similar

477.44.text: to the low oxygen down there.

483.14.text:
that if they entered
these healthy people,

485.16.text:
so people like you and I sat
around today and took them

488.58.text:
to high altitude, they
could look at who did well

491.27.text:
and who did badly at high
altitude, look at them

495.18.text: from the outside, but also look

496.38.text:
at all their physiological
parameters and measure lots

498.79.text:
of things going on in
their blood and body,

501.34.text: and they could see who did well

502.79.text:
and who did badly
in front of us.

504.45.text:
They could then look at
the people who did well

506.95.text:
when they walked up a high
mountain and see, well,

509.99.text:
what were they doing
or what were they doing

511.89.text:
that was different to those
that were doing very badly.

514.41.text:
What was it that was
allowing them to cope well

516.39.text:
and functionally be lucid, such
as down on the top of Everest?

519.71.text:
What was it that was allowing
him to do so well at the top

522.49.text:
of Everest whereas
if I tried strolling

524.22.text:
up there I would
certainly do very badly?

525.58.text:
And so they could then find what
allows some people to do well

529.13.text: in those low levels of oxygen.

531.28.text:
They could translate that back
into the intensive care unit,

533.73.text:
and perhaps allow people
in the intensive care unit

536.29.text:
to cope better with
low levels of oxygen.

538.27.text:
For example, if they found
there was a certain molecule

541.86.text:
in the blood of the,
in the, you know,

543.62.text:
high levels of a certain
molecule in the blood of people

546.09.text:
who coped very bad, very
well at high altitude,

548.70.text:
they could perhaps
synthesize that molecule,

550.70.text:
give it to the unwell patients
in intensive care units,

552.90.text:
and allow them to perhaps
cope better with the hypoxic

558.10.text:
that people obviously
encounter in intensive care.

561.08.text:
So that's really why we
did the expedition in 2007.

565.88.text:
Why we're going to
go back again.

569.85.text:
from a high-altitude environment
that mirrors the intensive care

575.06.text:
It is, indeed, an
unorthodox approach.

578.97.text:
People are now really accepting
it, but in 2007, when they went

583.59.text:
there were a lot of
skeptics among us.

585.49.text:
And Sir Edmund Hillary,
the legend that he is,

587.71.text:
certainly didn't help
our cause when he wrote

590.56.text:
that nobody climbs mountains
for scientific reasons.

594.91.text:
Science is used to raise
money for the expedition,

597.62.text:
but you can really climb
for the hell of it.

600.05.text: So as much as I respect him,

601.54.text:
he certainly didn't make
things very easy for us.

605.11.text: When we, in 2007, we did summit.

606.88.text:
We're not summiting this
so we can, you know,

611.28.text:
And people do argue
that, you know,

614.92.text:
this is just a boys club
climbing up mountains.

617.25.text:
Certainly it didn't in 2007, but
it's become much more understood

620.39.text:
and respected now, and,
certainly, we've had hundreds

623.01.text:
of publications from 2007, and
it is widely respected now.

627.06.text:
Some people do ask,
and very rightly,

630.52.text:
why do we not just put
people in a chamber.

632.27.text:
So at altitude, we are
suffering from a low oxygen,

636.16.text:
which is derived from
the low pressure.

638.41.text:
We could theoretically
do this in a chamber,

640.38.text:
or one of these chambers,
either of these chambers.

643.06.text:
The chamber on the
left as you look

644.98.text:
at is actually a
chamber we have at UCL,

648.95.text:
and that is a normal-pressure
chamber,

651.54.text:
and we just turn the
oxygen levels down really.

653.35.text:
So we can turn the levels
down to about 11 percent.

657.17.text:
Normal oxygen levels here
are about 21 percent.

659.74.text:
So the chamber on the right
is one with our collaborators

663.06.text:
at Duke in America, which
is we alter the pressure,

667.80.text:
And they certainly
do have their place.

669.31.text:
We can do many more invasive
trials and look at people

672.90.text:
because they're almost
in a hospital setting,

675.36.text:
but they are very
expensive to buy.

676.68.text:
They're very expensive to run,
and I can almost guarantee

679.77.text:
that if I offered anyone here
the chance to [inaudible]

682.20.text:
over three weeks or sit into a
tiny box about the size of this

686.36.text:
for three weeks, most
people would probably opt

693.00.text:
So a chamber does
have its place,

695.41.text:
but not on large-scale
expeditions such as ones we do.

701.49.text:
That's why we do it, and the
first expedition was called

705.45.text:
It was named after our major
sponsor, James [Inaudible].

709.52.text:
This expedition ended up
putting 24 people on the summit

714.15.text:
of Everest, and it
was led by the chap

716.12.text:
in the very center
called Mike Grocott,

720.54.text:
it's actually credit,
thanks to him.

722.13.text:
He's got the UCL flag on the top
of Everest, proudly bearing it.

728.38.text:
So when they went
to Everest in 2007,

731.39.text:
bearing in mind what we've
just talked about briefly,

733.03.text:
what were the questions
they had in mind?

736.46.text:
Well, they wanted to see
what governs performance

739.77.text:
or how well one does at altitude
in that low level oxygen.

743.55.text:
We are using altitude
as the case for,

747.57.text:
really for the lower
oxygen it provides.

749.39.text:
So what governs how
well one does

751.60.text: in the low levels of oxygen.

753.55.text:
Is it to do with how much
oxygen they have in their body?

756.03.text:
Is it to do with how
they deliver that oxygen

757.82.text:
around their body,
or is it to do

759.77.text: with how your body uses oxygen?

761.75.text:
Do they become a
bit more efficient

763.11.text:
with using what little
oxygen they have?

765.83.text:
Could they manipulate important
mechanisms to alter outcome?

769.53.text:
If it's, you know, if
it was all down to DNA,

771.56.text:
then perhaps we wouldn't
be able to bring

773.03.text:
that into the hospital
setting and alter someone's DNA

775.17.text: because we can't really do that.

777.12.text:
But were there things that
we could theoretically find

779.00.text:
that we could translate
to the hospital setting.

781.73.text:
And also they did want to look
at are genetics important.

784.64.text:
Is it all down to
genetics or not?

790.21.text:
And the way this expedition
works is that they got lots

794.50.text:
of healthy volunteers, and
I should say that everyone

797.81.text:
who goes on the expedition has
an investigator, such as myself,

800.41.text:
has to do exactly what their
volunteers do plus a lot,

804.17.text:
So I know there's
some subjects here

805.41.text:
in the audience, and
I feel your pain.

808.14.text:
And I'm hobbling because
I've had a muscle biopsy,

809.73.text:
which we haven't
made anyone else do.

813.08.text:
So we get about 200
healthy people, like I said,

815.53.text:
that's kind of a homogenous
population, and we get them

818.78.text:
in groups of 14, and they
come to our lab in London,

821.69.text:
or when 2007 they
came to lab in London.

823.79.text:
They had some experiments
done on themselves,

825.84.text:
and we could then see what
happened to their body

828.42.text:
or what is happening
in their body

830.27.text:
when they are in
21 percent oxygen.

834.57.text:
We'll then fly them out in
their groups of 14 to Nepal

843.10.text:
and we repeat all
the same experiments.

845.01.text:
And so we've turned down the
knob in the hospital setting,

847.48.text:
we're turning down
the oxygen levels,

849.06.text:
and we repeat everything again,
and we can now say, well,

851.07.text:
has anything changed if we
turn the oxygen levels down.

853.78.text:
They then stroll up to about
three and a half thousand meters

856.40.text:
up through the valleys, and we
repeat again everything to see,

860.29.text:
well, now they've got the third
amount of oxygen that they had

865.52.text:
And then the group of 200, in
their groups of 14 [inaudible]

868.45.text:
by four days, strolled up to
five and a half thousand meters,

871.17.text:
which is Everest base camp, and,
again, we did everything again.

874.57.text:
So we could see progressively
as we were turning

876.77.text:
down the oxygen level on
people what was happening

879.83.text:
Who was starting to
feel absolutely awful?

881.72.text:
Who was coping very
well, indeed.

884.72.text:
We also then sent
some investigators.

886.78.text:
We had about 50 investigators
out there.

888.63.text:
We sent some of them higher
and higher up the mountain.

890.52.text:
So from five and a half thousand
meters, some went up to six

893.17.text:
and a half thousand, some
went up to eight and a half,

895.10.text:
and some went just below
9,000 to the summit of Everest

897.98.text:
where they did take things
such as an exercise bike right

900.11.text:
up to just below the
top to exercise test

902.75.text:
and continue doing what we had
subjected everyone else to.

906.00.text:
So it was really an
observational study

909.08.text:
of what was happening as we
were turning down that oxygen,

916.34.text:
This is not Everest, but
does anyone actually know

925.49.text:
This is not, and many of
you may have been here.

928.99.text:
Many of you may not,
but this is Kilimanjaro,

932.43.text:
which is just a shade
under 6,000 meters.

934.48.text: So it is a bit higher.

935.28.text:
If you were to sat on top of
that, you are a bit higher

939.08.text:
The problem with this mountain,
it's a very nice mountain,

941.08.text:
it looks very nice,
is that it's also one

943.03.text:
of the most dangerous
mountains in the world.

945.07.text:
Not because it is
difficult to climb

947.24.text:
because lots of people
walk up it.

949.40.text:
I'll not take anything away
from some people who do it,

951.65.text:
but it is because it is
relatively easy to climb

953.69.text:
that lots of people do attempt
it, and they can almost run

955.83.text:
up this mountain, and people do
try running up this mountain.

959.31.text:
At 6,000 meters, you really
have to take things slowly,

962.24.text:
and the danger of
this mountain is

963.79.text:
that everyone's getting altitude
sickness, more and more people

966.03.text:
because they do try and
rush up this mountain.

968.48.text:
You should ascend, perhaps,
a couple of hundred meters,

971.10.text:
500 meters a day, and
people are trying to run up

972.98.text:
and down this mountain
in two or three days.

975.46.text: So people do get very ill.

978.35.text:
And on this subject of
the altitude sickness,

979.92.text:
we're just going to do a
little bit of physiology.

983.58.text: So when one goes to altitude,

986.98.text:
various things happen
to your body.

988.20.text:
We have turned the
oxygen levels down.

989.63.text:
So your body has
to try and cope,

990.80.text:
and it has to take
its time to cope.

992.30.text:
We can't just run up Kilimanjaro
because then our body hasn't got

995.97.text:
that time to go through
the physiological changes

1001.15.text:
Well, if we think back to Dan,
who's just come off the summit

1005.16.text:
of Everest, his heart was
beating a lot, lot quicker.

1008.41.text:
His lungs, he was
breathing a lot more.

1010.54.text:
So he was getting
more oxygen in,

1012.52.text:
getting rid of his
carbon dioxide,

1013.84.text:
and when that oxygen
was in the lungs,

1015.70.text:
his heart was beating
very quickly,

1018.36.text:
He had also increased his
red blood cell numbers.

1021.78.text:
So the little cells that
carry oxygen around the body.

1024.06.text:
So these are some of the
basic things that do happen

1026.17.text:
at altitude, but it does
take time, and if you do rush

1029.95.text:
up mountains, you
can get very ill.

1032.51.text:
So these are some of the things
we looked at in 2007 to look

1037.27.text:
at how people were
coping and was it purely

1040.37.text:
Was the person next
doing so much better

1042.10.text:
because he was breathing
far quicker?

1043.91.text:
His heart may be
pumping quicker.

1045.35.text:
His oxygen levels had gone
on, but what did we find?

1048.52.text:
So in 2007, we do see on this
graph, it's a bit complex, but,

1052.88.text:
really, it just shows as you
go higher up the mountain,

1056.83.text:
the oxygen levels, which are
the white bars, are dropping.

1060.48.text:
Your oxygen saturations,
which are the bars next to it,

1064.28.text:
are dropping, but your red
blood cell number is increasing.

1069.06.text:
So it's going up and up and
up as you're slowly walking

1071.27.text:
up the mountain over
about 14 or 15 days.

1073.28.text:
So you are getting more
oxygen, more red blood cells

1078.12.text:
in your body, and
you're able to carry

1080.87.text:
So is it down to
the fact that those
